FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES



House of Flavors is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68, and other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.



Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.



House of Flavors is located at 109 N. William Street, Ludington, Michigan. We manufacture some of the finest ice cream in the world. The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, three Ammonia refrigeration engine rooms, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. Also located at the facility is raw milk processing equipment, shipping and receiving docks.



The refrigeration systems required for our production and freezer processes necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. The refrigeration systems contain approximately of 27,700 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.



House of Flavors has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.



Our safety programs focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERG

ENCY RESPONSE POLICY



It is the policy of House of Flavors to conduct business in a manner that is safe to the employees, the community, and the environment. The company's officers, managers, and supervisors are accountable to carry out the policies of the company relevant to the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous materials. House of Flavors has made a determined effort to develop a plan to prevent releases of extremely hazardous substances. Procedures to assist in the prevention of extremely hazardous material releases are set forth in EPA's Risk Management Program. In the event of a release, the Emergency Response Plan will be the guidance for responding to, containing and reporting such releases.  The Response Plan includes an incident command system for decision making authority for each stage of a release situation.  The company will coordinate with public responders and emergency services in ensuring safety of the public.





RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



House of Flavors has set forth in its policies the importance of operating safely.  The company has aggressively developed programs, policies and materials requirements to minimize the possibility of releases. These programs include compliance with appropriate OSHA and EPA regulations and sound safety practices. Stringent material and contractor requirements have been developed to assure that materials and work conform to recognized standards. Training for employees is conducted to maintain a high level awareness when working with hazardous materials.



As part of the Prevention Program, House of Flavors has developed a method to evaluate the Risk Management Program. This method includes periodic evaluation of the Program utilizing a Process Hazard Analysis, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Compliance Audits.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



House of Flavors has no reportable incident as defined in 40 CFR 68.42(a) during the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



Preparations for

an emergency including, but not limited to: Fire, Release of hazardous chemicals including ammonia, Bomb Threat, Inclement weather, Civil Disorder, Hostile labor, Flood, Loss of water, Loss of electricity, Terrorist activities or disruptions due to governmental inspections, which may occur. Also set up an adequate chain of command during an emergency to minimize the impact of an emergency on employee health and safety. Minimize the impact of an emergency on our neighbors and the environment. Follow up emergency procedures. Our Program is coordinated with the Mason County LEPC.



SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS



Future changes to improve release prevention include: improved maintenance procedures, addition of new technology as it becomes available; and continued training of plant and response personnel. Our facility is constantly striving to "Lead the Field" in industrial safety. Our goal is and has been to be a responsible corporate citizen, protecting people and the environment. In the last 12 months our Program has undergone an extensive re-write. Our programs will continue to be reviewed (On a 12 month cycle) and updated as necessary.
